author: Sarah D.
title: British GQ writer asks if Obama could kill Trump (but donâ€™t worry â€” it was just â€˜a jokeâ€™)
text:
â€” Dan Ornelas (@DanielMOrnelas) January 11, 2017 
This election cycle has shown an unflattering light on a lot of people, but the media may very well have come out looking worse than anyone. And thatâ€™s thanks in no small part to people like Rupert Myers. 
Myers, political correspondent for British GQ and the Telegraph, decided it would be a good idea to tweet this out earlier today: Members of the press continue to adjust to the post-Nov. 8 world with commendable grace and charm. pic.twitter.com/jUdpe99GN0 
â€” T. Becket Adams (@BecketAdams) January 11, 2017 
Myersâ€™ tweet didnâ€™t stay up for long. Why did you delete this tweet, @RupertMyers ? 
Imagine a conservative said this in '08 about Obama. pic.twitter.com/4E7HhFYAKQ 
â€” Harry Khachatrian (@Harry1T6) January 11, 2017 @Harry1T6 it was a joke that I quickly realised could be taken out of context. you've proved my point 
â€” Rupert Myers (@RupertMyers) January 11, 2017 
Ah. So itâ€™s readersâ€™ fault for failing to get his crappy â€œjoke.â€ Myers didnâ€™t delete the tweet because he felt bad about it; he did it because he didnâ€™t like being called out for his jackassery. LOL guys it's really not that slow a news day. I was just wondering if the president could pardon himself ğŸ˜‚ pic.twitter.com/i6GNmaB9c3 
â€” Rupert Myers (@RupertMyers) January 11, 2017 
Except thatâ€™s not what he asked. And now, heâ€™s paying for it: I'm in the middle of a small tweetstorm being attacked by truly daft & entirely humourless Trump supporters pic.twitter.com/2I2jXnMWkh 
â€” Rupert Myers (@RupertMyers) January 11, 2017 
What a shame. 
â€” Scills Matthews (@scillsygirl) January 11, 2017 You called for the president elect to be murderedâ€¦â€¦ https://t.co/aWs2aMl2sU
